turns.content: I use a very specific JSON structure that I call Lollipop JSON to represent a web page. I want to teach you Lollipop JSON and the rules so that you can help me make web pages.
Sure! I'm happy to learn about Lollipop JSON and help you make web pages using it. Please tell me more about the structure and rules of Lollipop JSON.

Lollipop JSON is overall a dictionary. There are 2 top level nodes, "elements" and "workflows". "elements" can have 1 - many children, where each child represents an element. Some possible elements include Text, and Button. I will teach you exactly how to represent an element. The other top level node other than "elements" is "workflows". Each child of "workflows" represents a single workflow, and describes some kind of trigger and action taken. I will also teach you exactly how to represent a workflow.

Thanks for the explanation! It sounds like Lollipop JSON has a specific structure and rules for defining elements and workflows.

Please teach me how to represent an element and a workflow in Lollipop JSON.

Thanks for the example! It looks like the Lollipop JSON representation for an element includes a unique identifier, properties, type, id, default\_name, and style.

Can you also teach me how to represent a workflow in Lollipop JSON?

Thank you for the additional example! It's clear that the Lollipop JSON representation for a button also includes a unique identifier, properties, type, id, default\_name, and style.

Now, can you teach me how to represent a workflow in Lollipop JSON?

You can also represent a shape. Here is an example of a shape element - 

"bTGzy": {
 "properties": {
 "height": 50,
 "left": 50,
 "top": 50,
 "width": 50,
 "zindex": 6,
 "border\_roundness": 50,
 "bgcolor": "rgb(255,125,125,0.8)"
 },
 "type": "Shape",
 "id": "bTGzz",
 "default\_name": "Shape A"
 }

Notice the type is Shape here.

Thank you for the additional example! It's clear that the Lollipop JSON representation for a shape also includes a unique identifier, properties, type, id, and default\_name.

Now, let's move on to workflows. Can you teach me how to represent a workflow in Lollipop JSON?

Thanks for the example! It looks like the Lollipop JSON representation for a workflow includes a unique identifier, properties, type, id, and actions.

The properties seem to include some metadata about the workflow, such as the element\_id that represents the initial trigger.

The actions seem to include a set of actions that should be executed when the workflow is triggered. Each action seems to include properties that represent the element involved in the action, the type of action, and the id of the action.

It's also interesting to note that when a workflow refers to other elements, it uses those elements' reference ids, such as "bTGzi" in this example.

Overall, it seems like Lollipop JSON has a specific structure and set of rules for representing elements and workflows. Do you have any more examples or questions for me?

Thats great. Now, using Lollipop JSON, let's create a page that has 3 shapes in cool tones. Under each shape, have some text with a more detailed description of the shape's color, and under each text, have a button that does something.
